Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for assistance in moving a few boxes while moving to a new apartment.
Expectation2: Communicate clearly and empathetically with patients and their families
Situation2: A patient has received a new diagnosis for a chronic condition and has many questions about managing it.
Story: I was just finishing my shift at the hospital when I got a text from Mark, an old college acquaintance. He was moving to a new apartment and asked if I could help him move a few boxes that evening. I remembered how, years ago, he’d helped me out when I was in a bind, and I felt a tug of obligation to return the favor. At the same time, as I was about to leave, Mrs. Patel’s daughter stopped me in the hallway. Her mother had just been diagnosed with diabetes, and she looked overwhelmed, clutching a notepad full of questions. I could see the worry in her eyes, and I knew how important it was to take the time to explain everything clearly and compassionately. I felt torn—on one hand, I wanted to be there for Mark, to show I valued our connection and repay his kindness. On the other, I knew my patient and her family needed my support and expertise right now. The weight of both expectations pressed on me, and I stood in the hallway, my phone buzzing in my pocket, unsure which role I could let down.
